approval_data.project_summary: This project is a simple web application to manage a list of tasks.
project_goals: Allow a user to add a task
Allow a user to see their list of tasks
approval_data.business_context: The project aims to provide a basic web application for personal task management.

requirements.description: A user can create a new task with a text description.
A user can see a list of all created tasks.

functional_requirements: A user can create a new task with a text description.
A user can see a list of all created tasks.
success_criteria: Users can successfully add new tasks.
Users can view their complete list of tasks.
The application loads in an acceptable timeframe.
The application is protected against common security vulnerabilities.
assumptions: The application will be a web-based interface.
Tasks will only consist of a text description.

recommendations: Define specific metrics for 'load quickly' (e.g., page load time under X seconds).
Define specific security requirements (e.g., adherence to OWASP Top 10, data encryption).
Identify and list all key stakeholders.
Define success criteria more explicitly with measurable outcomes.
Identify potential constraints (e.g., budget, technology stack, timeline).
Document assumptions made during the project definition.
Consider additional functional requirements like editing, deleting, or marking tasks as complete.
Address data persistence (how tasks are stored and retrieved).

identified_gaps: Lack of detailed non-functional requirements (specific performance metrics, security standards).
Missing explicit success criteria beyond basic functionality.
Missing common task management features (e.g., edit task, delete task, mark task as complete).
No mention of data storage or persistence mechanisms.
No user authentication or authorization mentioned.
recommendations_for_completion: Conduct workshops with business users and technical teams to elaborate on NFRs and define measurable targets.
Identify and engage all relevant stakeholders (e.g., product owner, developers, testers, end-users).
Define clear, measurable, achievable, relevant, and time-bound (SMART) success criteria.
Document all known constraints (e.g., technology, budget, timeline) and assumptions (e.g., user environment, data volume).
Perform a risk assessment to identify and plan mitigation strategies for potential project risks.
Explore additional core functional requirements for a task list application (e.g., CRUD operations beyond create and read).
Specify how tasks will be stored (e.g., database, local storage) and retrieved.
Consider if user accounts or authentication are required for future scalability.
